Award.AwardTitle: Global Engagement and Collaboration: Strategic Initiatives of the U.S. National Committees for the Geosciences
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides support for the U.S. annual dues to four, separate International Geoscience Unions that are part of the International Council for Science (ICSU): International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics (IUGG), International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS), International Union of Soil Sciences (IUSS), and International Union for Quaternary Research (INQUA). This award also provides support for the U.S. National committees (USNC) to each of these Unions. The role of the USNC?s is to facilitate participation of American scientists in the activities of the international unions, engage the U.S. community in advancing geosciences in the U.S. and abroad; establish strong links to and foster communications with the respective international unions; exercise U.S. leadership in these unions; develop a globally aware U.S. geoscience community that collaborates internationally; and support the development of early-career U.S. geoscientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. National Committees (USNCs) for the International Union for Soil Science (IUSS), the International Union for Geological Sciences (IUGS), the International Union for Geodesy and Geophysics (IUGG), and the International Union for Quaternary Research (INQUA) are housed in the Board of International Scientific Organizations at the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine (NASEM). This award allowed the NASEM and these four USNCs to represent the U.S. to their respective unions on scientific and governance issues, catalyze and facilitate the participation of the U.S. scientific community in these unions, organize activities to support U.S. geoscience, and support U.S. geoscience students and early career scientists.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The unions are long-standing organizations that emphasize initiation and promotion of international scientific programs, development of services and products, and international research cooperation in their respective disciplinary areas. They involve the participation of thousands of international scientists and of U.S. scientists from academia, Federal agencies, and non-profits. U.S. scientists very frequently have positions of leadership, both at the governance level and at the project and activity levels. For example, in 2017, 77 U.S. researchers participated in IUGS programs and projects, the most of any member country. Having U.S. scientists in leadership positions allows U.S. positions and priorities to have greater visibility. 

The USNCs organize activities that complement and/or expand upon activities the unions undertake for the benefit of U.S. geoscientists and society. They communicate U.S. and international opportunities and information to the U.S. community via websites and social media. The USNCs for the geosciences take special interest in advancing U.S. science and scientists, especially those at the earlier stages of their careers. The role of the USNCs is unique and reflects the complexity of science: both as a catalyst for new ways to approach science and as entities that represent the U.S. abroad. 

For example, members of the USNC/Soils wrote “Soil and Human Security in the 21st Century,” a review paper published in Science in May 2015 that shows the relationships and linkages between soils and the many aspects of life on Earth and the impact on society, well beyond the academic study of soils. To date, the paper/pdf were downloaded almost 15,800 times, has been cited 364 times in scholarly works, and still ranks in the top 5% of all Altmetric-scored research outputs.

USNC members and staff also have organized several scientific sessions at various organizations including the Geological Society of America, the American Geophysical Union, and the International Union for Quaternary Research on topics as diverse as science diplomacy, interdisciplinary work, and the application of Quaternary research to societal problems. Activities on these topics link the geosciences to ways to improve interactions among stakeholders and to use basic science to benefit humanity.

BROADER IMPACT

 “Soils: the Foundation of Life”: Elements of the Science paper mentioned above inspired this 2016 NAS workshop. Many stakeholders do not necessarily see the links between soils and topics such as water quality and availability, food security, human health biodiversity, environmental change, critical infrastructure, and national security. This workshop, webcast live and with all presentations now posted online, increased public and policymakers’ awareness of the multidimensionality of the contributions of soils to economy and security of our nation, and facilitated interactions among soil scientists and those from other disciplines, and between soil scientists from very diverse sub-disciplines. Live tweeting reached many thousands of people, and an article on this work was published in EOS, the magazine of the American Geophysical Union. The Soils: the Foundation of Life NASEM proceedings was downloaded ~1,100 times. This workshop, in turn, was the root of the 2018 National Conference on Connections between Soil Health and Human Health.

The USNC/IUGS works with its program development activity, the Advisory Group for Geoparks and Geoheritage, by working with academia, non-profits, industry, and government agencies to support geoheritage initiatives in the U.S. and thus help protect the U.S. natural patrimony and preserve it for future geoscience research, education, and recreation for all Americans.

Increasing diversity has been a priority for the USNCs. USNC membership and U.S. delegations to union governance meetings are now more diverse in gender, ethnic origin, career stage, and geographic factors. Moreover, the 8-member U.S. delegation to the IUGS GA had six female members, including the chair, and two were underrepresented minorities.

Finally, the USNCs organized initiatives to further U.S. scientists’ professional development: two mentoring sessions in collaboration with the American Quaternary Association, reaching 90 students and early career scientists. An article on the mentoring activity at the 2018 American Quaternary Association/Canadian Quaternary Association meeting appeared in PAGES magazine. USNCs managed and supported the mentoring component of separately funded travel awards programs for the IUSS and IUGS international congresses. These programs supported 38 U.S. students and early career scientists to present their research and make new scientificcontacts.
